wiki.content:
Moon Over Bourbon Street appears on Sting's 1985 debut solo album ‘The Dream of the Blue Turtles’. The track became the fourth and final track from the album to be released as a single, peaking the #44 position in the UK. Played throughout the 1985/86 tour, a live version of the track recorded in Arnhem can be found on the ‘Bring on The Night’ album. The song made a surprise but welcome reappearance on the ‘Brand New Day’ tour, where it was given a new lease of life thanks to Chris Botti's trumpet and Sting's gravelly vocals - a cross between Tom Waits and Louis Armstrong.
 
 In 2003, Sting re-recorded ‘Moon’ as a B-side on the CD-single ‘Send Your Love’, which hit as high as #30 in the UK music charts. The re-recording includes a solo acoustic guitar accompanying the vocals, giving the song a modern combination of blues and latino rhythms. TBS chose ‘Moon’ as the ending theme song for the Japanese drama Loved to Love, probably to fit the dancing style of Kuroki Hitomi's character in the series.
 
 "Moon Over Bourbon Street’ was originally written to describe a character from Anne Rice's "Interview with a Vampire".
        
User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.
wiki.summary: Moon Over Bourbon Street appears on Sting's 1985 debut solo album ‘The Dream of the Blue Turtles’. The track became the fourth and final track from the album to be released as a single, peaking the #44 position in the UK. Played throughout the 1985/86 tour, a live version of the track recorded in Arnhem can be found on the ‘Bring on The Night’ album. The song made a surprise but welcome reappearance on the ‘Brand New Day’ tour, where it was given a new lease of life thanks to Chris Botti's trumpet and Sting's gravelly vocals - a cross between Tom Waits and Louis Armstrong.

track.name: Moon Over Bourbon Street
comments: Who knew he could mangle his own work like this?
Prefer the first version--it always shows when he;s trying too hard

Brrr... love this song
Scary but sensuous, as (some) vampires ;)
Aren't we all Vampires to a degree?
Vampires here.
Kudos to Branford Marsalis

Because of this song, I always wish they'd had Sting play the part of LeStat in the movie- NOT TOM CRUISE!-  Sting would've been perfect-you know already a rock star/charisma/looks/perfect movie theme song and everything .....
The song has the same melody as Autumn Leaves
to my mind police was a bit more extraodinary
One can see here why he was so desperate to quit The Police.
Vampires...
lovely (:
I must love what I destroy  and destroy the things a love! Brilliant line..
Very accessible jam, right?
Awesome... the song that made Anne Rice famous!
Great !!!
What other versiond are there?? I'd love to hear em too.
Best version of that song I know!
Werewolf Sting!^^
Sting is a genius.......love the jazzy music
